content:
@BWPanda It's of course unrelated to bee but I am testing this out and it made me think of the bee project. :smile:
https://www.beekeeperstudio.io/

Thanks for that @Laryn :+1: ....I used to use https://www.heidisql.com and some free verisons of https://www.navicat.com on Windows. Then when I switched to MacOS for work, I started using http://sequelpro.com. ...Beekeeper Studio seems cool + it's open-source :heart:
@Laryn oooh, I've been looking for a better SQL manager. The one I use: MySQL ... I forget the name, but it's the official one, crashes too often
What are SQL managers for? Maybe I don't do enough database stuff, but whenever I need to use/access the DB I just use phpMyAdmin...

@BWPanda AFAIK phpMyAdmin implies that it is installed on the server. With SQL GUIs, you basically get an ssh tunnel into any server you have such access to (even local instances), and can then connect to the SQL instance. The features are basically the same as phpMyAdmin.
Have you tried https://www.adminer.org? Just one PHP file, plus one CSS for taste. Place it under password protected directory and you are done.
I had to use that once on a project. Didn't like it. Couldn't get used to the interface after using phpMyAdmin...
I personally prefer to avoid such monsters even when I work with dragon.

You can access remote databases with phpMyAdmin, but it requires opening up the port to outside access, if it isn't already. There is also a way to remotely access securely.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16801573/how-to-access-remote-server-with-local-phpmyadmin-client

How to access remote server with local phpMyAdmin client?
Assuming there is a remote server and I have phpMyAdmin client installed localy on my computer. How can I access this server and manage it via phpMyAdmin client? Is that possible?
With Lando or other local dev I often use an SQL manager but recently found out how to add phpmyadmin as a Lando service so that's an option.
